content.description:
In mammals, the dark color of skin, hair, and eyes is due to a pigment called melanin. Melanin is produced by specialized skin cells called melanocytes. The melanin is then transferred to other skin cells called keratinocytes. Melanocytes synthesize melanin in a multistep metabolic pathway (Figure 1). The amount of melanin produced is dependent on the amount of the enzymes <math alttext="T Y R" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>TYR</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="T R P 2" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>TRP2</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, and <math alttext="T R P 1" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>TRP1</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> present inside melanocytes.

Figure 1. Melanin synthesis pathway

The peptide hormone <math alttext="alpha" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>α</mi><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">–</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>melanocyte stimulating hormone (<math alttext="alpha M S H" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>α</mi><mrow><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">–</mo><mtext>MSH</mtext></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>) activates a signal transduction pathway leading to the activation of <math alttext="M I T F" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>MITF</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. <math alttext="M I T F" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>MITF</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is a transcription factor that increases the expression of the <math alttext="T Y R" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow><mi>T</mi><mi>Y</mi><mi>R</mi></mrow></math>, <math alttext="T R P 2" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>T</mi><mi>R</mi><mi>P</mi><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mn>2</mn></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>, and <math alttext="T R P 1" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>T</mi><mi>R</mi><mi>P</mi><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mn>1</mn></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> genes (Figure 2).

Figure 2. Activation of melanin synthesis genes in melanocytes

Some mammals increase melanin production in response to ultraviolet <math alttext="or U V" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mtext>UV</mtext><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> radiation. The <math alttext="U V" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>UV</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> radiation causes damage to <math alttext="D N A" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>DNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> in keratinocytes, which activates the <math alttext="p 53" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>p53</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> protein. <math alttext="p 53" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>p53</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> increases the expression of the <math alttext="P O M C" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>P</mi><mi>O</mi><mi>M</mi><mi>C</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> gene. The <math alttext="P O M C" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>POMC</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> protein is then cleaved to produce <math alttext="alpha M S H" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>α</mi><mrow><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">–</mo><mtext>MSH</mtext></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. The keratinocytes secrete <math alttext="alpha M S H" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow><mi>α</mi><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">–</mo><mtext>MSH</mtext></mrow></math>, which signals nearby melanocytes. The increased melanin absorbs <math alttext="U V" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>UV</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> radiation, reducing further <math alttext="D N A" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>DNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> damage.

Figure 3. Production of <math alttext="alpha M S H" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow><mi>α</mi><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">–</mo><mtext>MSH</mtext></mrow></math> in keratinocytes in response to <math alttext="U V" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow><mtext>UV</mtext></mrow></math> radiation
content.question:
Researchers discovered a mutant form of the <math alttext="T Y R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>T</mi><mi>Y</mi><mi>R</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> gene with a deletion of a single guanine nucleotide in the beginning of the coding sequence.

Which of the following best predicts the phenotype of an individual who is homozygous for this <math alttext="T Y R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>T</mi><mi>Y</mi><mi>R</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> mutation?

choices.label: The mutation will cause a single amino acid change in the <math alttext="T Y R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>TYR</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> protein, which will not be enough to disrupt its function. Therefore, those with this mutation will produce melanin in the hair, skin, and eyes and tan in response to <math alttext="U V" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>UV</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> radiation.

The mutation will cause a single amino acid change in the <math alttext="T Y R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>TYR</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> protein, leading to a nonfunctional <math alttext="T Y R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>TYR</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> protein. Therefore, those with this mutation will lack melanin in the hair, skin, and eyes and will not tan in response to <math alttext="U V" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>UV</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> radiation.

The mutation will change all subsequent amino acids in the <math alttext="T Y R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>TYR</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> protein, leading to nonfunctional <math alttext="T Y R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>TYR</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> protein. Since the <math alttext="T R P 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mrow><mi>T</mi><mi>R</mi><mi>P</mi><mn>1</mn></mrow></mstyle><mtext></mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="T R P 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="italic"><mrow><mi>T</mi><mi>R</mi><mi>P</mi><mn>2</mn></mrow></mstyle><mtext></mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> genes were not affected, the <math alttext="T R P 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>TRP1</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="T R P 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>TRP2</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> proteins will fill the role of the <math alttext="T Y R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>TYR</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> protein. Therefore, those with this mutation will produce melanin in the hair, skin, and eyes in response to <math alttext="U V" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>UV</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> radiation.

The mutation will change all subsequent amino acids in the <math alttext="T Y R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>TYR</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> protein, leading to nonfunctional <math alttext="T Y R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>TYR</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> protein. Individuals with this mutation will lack melanin in their hair, skin, and eyes and will not tan in response to <math alttext="U V " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>UV</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> radiation.
